prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. So the user is asking whether the author is at fault here. The situation is about a friend who has five kids by different fathers and is single, and the author told her that this is why it's hard to find a partner. The friend got really upset and hung up. Now mutual friends are saying the author is in the wrong because of things like "skinny privilege" and being entitled.

First, I need to consider the context. The author was getting insulted by their friend for two years with comments about her body, dating life, and work. The friend's remarks were personal and seemed to be a way to deflect from her own issues. The author finally responded by pointing out the friend's situation with the five kids and child support. 

The key points here: Was the author justified in responding as they did? The friend's comments were rude and personal, so the author might have felt they were being attacked. However, when responding, the author brought up the friend's personal circumstances, which could be seen as attacking her for her choices. 

Even if the friend was being mean, the author's response could be seen as cutting and potentially shaming her. The mutual friends think the author is privileged and doesn't understand her struggles. The author works in the adult industry, which might be a sensitive topic, but they also have an MBA and a stable income. The friend tried to work in the same field, so maybe that's a point of contention. 

Is it fair to tell someone that their personal choices (having multiple children with different partners) are the reason they're struggling? It's possible the author was trying to be honest, but the way they delivered it might have been harsh. The friend could take it as a personal attack, even if it's true. The author might not have considered the emotional impact of their words. 

Also, the author's own situation is different—they have two kids with the same father, so maybe the friend felt they couldn't relate. The author's job in the adult industry might be a point of judgment, but the friend also tried that, so maybe that's why she comments on it. 

The mutual friends' reactions suggest that the author's response was hurtful. Even if the author was tired of being insulted, responding with a direct critique of the friend's personal life might not have been the best approach. It's possible that the author could have addressed the insults without attacking the friend's situation, perhaps by setting boundaries or not engaging. 

In terms of right or wrong, it's a bit of a gray area. The author was defending themselves against insults, but the method might have been inappropriate. The friend's behavior was unkind, but the author's response could have been seen as crossing a line. The friends might be right in saying that the author's response was harsh, even if the insults were unwarranted. 

So, considering all that, the answer might be that the author is at fault because even if the friend was being mean, the response was potentially hurtful and didn't address the insults in a constructive way. The author could have handled it better without making personal attacks.
